0	0	http://reuters.com/article/us-new-york-budget-idUSKCN0YU2GN	New York City reaches agreement on $82.1 billion FY 2017 budget	"

NEW YORK New York's Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Wednesday an agreement on a balanced $82.1 billion city budget for the 2016-2017 fiscal year that boosts reserves and expands a summer youth employment program. The agreement was reached with New York's City Council and comes well ahead of a July 1 deadline. De Blasio
column2: a Democrat
column3: said it was the earliest agreement since 2001 and credited the cooperation between his administration and the City Council.The agreement increases reserves
column4: with an additional $250 million to grow the Retiree Health Benefits Trust Fund to $3.9 billion. It includes $1 billion every year in general reserves
column5: and $500 million in the capital stabilization reserve.The budget highlights de Blasio's social mission. The executive budget
column7: dedicated $2 billion to overhauling the city's $7.5 billion public hospital system
column8: which treat around 1.4 million people per year.

column1: City Council Speaker Melissa Mark-Viverito and other council members hailed the expansion of the city's summer youth work program to 60
column2: 000 at a press conference at City Hall. The program places young people aged 14-24 with community organizations for summer employment.

column1: The budget agreement comes at a difficult time for de Blasio who is facing multiple investigations into his campaign finances. On Wednesday the head of New York City's prison guard union and a hedge fund financier were charged with operating a kickback scheme. It marked the first major prosecution to emerge from state and federal corruption probes examining de Blasio's fundraising practices
column2: among other avenues of inquiry.

column1: (Reporting by Edward Krudy; Editing by Andrew Hay)"	[]	[]

column2: Trump draw battle lines for ill-tempered campaign fight	"

column1: By Steve Holland
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump kicked off a fierce general election battle
column2: with Democrats accusing Trump of erratic behavior and the Republican threatening to bring up old Clinton scandals.           Clinton
column3: the former secretary of state
column4: made history when she became the first woman to lead a major political party in its quest to capture the U.S. presidency. Big primary election wins on Tuesday in California and elsewhere catapulted her to victory over Democratic opponent Bernie Sanders.If elected on Nov. 8
column5: the 68-year-old former U.S. senator from New York would return the Clinton family to the White House 16 years after her husband
column7: completed two terms as president.All signs point toward a negative campaign as Clinton accused Trump of being temperamentally unfit to serve and the New York businessman charged that Clinton had a dark past and a weak record as President Barack Obama's first-term secretary of state.Clinton told NBC on Wednesday she would not run a ""campaign of insults
column8: but she sought to portray the 69-year-old Trump as not fit for the Oval Office after the real estate developer repeatedly accused a Mexican-American judge of showing bias against him because of his ethnic heritage.The Clinton campaign has pointed to criticism from leaders in Trump's Republican Party to make this case.""I'm going to talk about why he's unqualified to be president based on his own words and his deeds. And I'm going to continue to make the case he is temperamentally unfit to be commander in chief
column9: she said in the interview.Trump gave a carefully crafted primary race victory speech on Tuesday laying out his own plan of attack. To keep from straying off message
column10: he used a Teleprompter and avoided his typical stream-of-consciousness delivery.Trump said money given to the Clinton Foundation charity from foreign donors had earned the Clintons millions of dollars and had a corrupting influence when Clinton was secretary of state.""Hillary Clinton turned the State Department into her private hedge fund - the Russians
column12: the Chinese - all gave money to Bill and Hillary and got favorable treatment in return. It's a sad day in America when foreign governments with deep pockets have more influence in our own country than our great citizens

column1: He said he would give a speech next week ""discussing all of the things that have taken place with the Clintons."" CLINTON LEADS
A Reuters/Ipsos poll on Tuesday showed Clinton leading Trump by 10 percentage points nationally
column2: little changed from a week earlier. [nL1N18Y1Z2]Both Clinton and Trump must unite their parties but the Democrat appeared to face the easier path with Sanders
column3: a leftist U.S. senator from Vermont
column4: nearly out of options to challenge her. Trump has an uphill battle. U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan described Trump's remarks about the judge as a ""textbook definition of a racist comment
column5: but said he would still support him.

column1: Trump said on Wednesday he was ""disappointed and surprised"" by charges of racism from Republicans. ""I had just won more votes than anyone in the history of the party
column2: he told Time. ""But you know
column3: they have to say what they have to say. I'm a big boy. They have to say what they have to say.""    Ryan met behind closed doors on Wednesday with House Republicans. An aide said Ryan ""discussed with his members the thinking behind his endorsement (of Trump) and how to move forward"" and reiterated he had confidence Trump would support the House Republican agenda.    ""I'd say the general attitude is
column4: 'Good. Now let's just move on
column5: '"" said U.S. Representative Chris Collins of New York
column6: a Trump supporter. ""The irony here and the frustration was that he's not racist.""Others said Trump needed to stop engaging in petty battles with former rivals and build a fundraising organization. Trump will meet on Thursday in New York with top fundraisers of the Republican National Committee

column1: Hopes flickered among some anti-Trump Republicans that there would be a revolt against him when delegates convene to nominate him formally in Cleveland from July 18 to 21. Representative Morgan Griffith
column2: a Virginia Republican
column3: said that was unlikely but that Trump needed to improve as a candidate.""Don't step into the cow pie
column4: Griffith said. ""He can't afford to be stepping into any more controversies like that.""Clinton edged Sanders out in a rough-and-tumble battle that stretched over four months and 50 states. She won support
column5: especially among older voters
column6: with a more pragmatic campaign focused on building on the policies of fellow Democrat Obama.Clinton said she had spoken to Sanders on Tuesday to congratulate him on his campaign.""I am looking forward to working with him to unify the Democratic Party against the threat that Donald Trump poses to our country
column7: she told PBS on Wednesday. ""So we are talking. We will be having an opportunity to discuss in greater detail in the days ahead how we can best work together.""    Democratic Party elites are lined up squarely behind Clinton
column9: who may endorse her as early as this week. White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest told reporters that Obama would not endorse until after he meets with Sanders on Thursday.Obama and Sanders have spoken three times in the past month
column10: Earnest said. The president's eventual endorsement would put pressure on Sanders to exit graciously and throw his support to Clinton. Sanders is also due to meet with Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid. (Additional reporting by Susan Heavey
column14: Roberta Rampton and Richard Cowan in Washington; Editing by Alistair Bell and Peter Cooney)"	['Sanders'

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-pennsylvania-liquor-idUSKCN0YU2OD	Pennsylvania governor signs law expanding wine sales to private stores	"
By Hilary Russ
Pennsylvania Governor Tom Wolf on Wednesday signed into law new measures to expand the sale of bottled wine to certain private stores
column2: a move that could generate millions in state revenues through taxes and licensing fees.Pennsylvania is one of just two U.S. states
column3: along with Utah
column4: with full control over its liquor sale system - owning and operating retail and wholesale operations.""This is truly a historic day for Pennsylvania and the most significant step the commonwealth has taken to reform our liquor system in 80 years
column5: Wolf said in a statement.

column1: The new legislation
column2: passed by lawmakers on Tuesday
column3: moves wine sales beyond the state's publicly run system
column4: allowing supermarkets
column5: convenience stores
column6: restaurants and hotels that already have licenses for carry-out beer to sell up to four bottles of wine to customers. [nL1N18Z1W7]

column1: It also expands direct wine shipments by the case; liquor
column2: wine and beer sales at casinos; and hours of operation at state stores
column3: including on Sundays. The move is expected to increase retail wine sales overall and could add more than $150 million to state coffers.The Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board is the largest purchaser of wine and spirits in the United States. The state has an 18 percent liquor tax.

column1: (Reporting by Hilary Russ in New York; Editing by Bernard Orr)"	['Wolf']	[]
4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-india-idUSKCN0YU1ZR	Modi wants deeper U.S.-India security relationship	"
By Patricia Zengerle and Megan Cassella
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi called for a closer security relationship between his country and the United States on Wednesday
column2: in an address to the U.S. Congress stressing the importance of warming ties between the two countries.He dedicated much of the speech to the importance of fighting terrorism
column3: thanking Congress for U.S. support after a Pakistan-based military group's rampage in Mumbai killed 166 people in 2008.""The fight against terrorism has to be fought at many levels. And the traditional tools of military
column4: intelligence or diplomacy alone would not be able to win this fight
column5: Modi told a rare joint meeting of the Senate and House of Representatives.""We have both lost civilians and soldiers in combating it. The need of the hour is for us to deepen our security cooperation
column6: Modi said.He leavened the speech to lawmakers
column7: the first such address by an international leader since Pope Francis' in September
column8: with jokes about Congress' bitter partisan divide and yoga. But Modi used it to make serious points about India's neighbor and arch-rival Pakistan and regional concerns about Chinese expansionism.""I commend the members of the U.S. Congress for sending a clear message to those who preach and practice terrorism for political gains
column10: not mentioning either country by name.    Modi is on the U.S. leg of an international tour. On Tuesday
column11: he met with President Barack Obama at the White House
column12: where the two leaders said India agreed to work toward joining the Paris Agreement on climate change this year and discussed security and cyber security issues.

column1: The visit
column2: two years after Modi became prime minister
column3: capped an improving relationship between New Delhi and the United States. Before he was elected
column4: Modi was barred from even entering the country because of concerns about his handling of 2002 riots that killed at least 1
column5: 000 people

column1: Today
column2: he is one of the international leaders most popular in Washington
column3: where Modi's government is seen as a counterbalance to China. He and Obama have a warm personal relationship.

column1: We are now standing shoulder to shoulder in ways that no one could have imagined a generation ago
column2: Representative Eliot Engel
column3: the top Democrat on the House Foreign Affairs committee
column4: said at a reception for Modi after the address. In a 45-minute speech interrupted by cheers and at least eight standing ovations
column5: the 65-year-old Indian leader said deeper U.S.-Indian security cooperation should isolate anyone who harbors
column6: supports or sponsors terrorists.Although he did not mention Pakistan
column7: that line was greeted with applause from the lawmakers
column8: many of whom are increasingly frustrated with what they see as Islamabad's failure to crack down on militants behind attacks on American troops in Afghanistan.

column1: Modi also stressed that India is committed to helping rebuild a peaceful and stable Afghanistan.Amid heightened tensions over China's assertive pursuit of territory in the South China Sea
column2: Modi said a stronger U.S.-India partnership could boost peace and prosperity ""from Asia to Africa and from the Indian Ocean to the Pacific."" He did not mention China.""It can also help ensure security of the sea lanes and commerce and freedom of navigation on seas
column3: Modi added.Democrats leaped to their feet when Modi referred to the recent climate change summit. But Republicans in the House chamber remained seated
column4: reflecting the U.S. political divide over the issue.House Speaker Paul Ryan greeted Modi at his office before his speech. After the Indian leader's remarks
column5: he attended lunch with congressional leaders and a reception with members of the House Foreign Affairs and Senate Foreign Relations committees. (Writing by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by James Dalgleish)"	['Paul'

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-tennessee-lgbt-idUSKCN0YU2IL	Two gay men challenge Tennessee denial of service law	"

Two men have filed a lawsuit against Tennessee and its governor saying their constitutional rights as gay individuals are violated by a new law that allows mental health counselors to refuse to treat patients on the basis of ""sincerely held principles.""The law
column2: signed by Republican Governor Bill Haslam in April
column3: has been criticized as discriminatory against the gay community.The lawsuit
column4: filed on Tuesday by Bleu Copas and Caleb Laieski in the Chancery Court for Anderson County
column5: asks the court to void the statute because it violates the Tennessee Constitution and the U.S. Constitution's 14th Amendment
column6: which guarantees equal protection to all citizens under the law.""LGBT (lesbian
column8: bisexual and transgender) persons were the target of the statute. They are singled out for discriminatory treatment. There is no other group which could conceivably be the target of the statute
column9: the lawsuit reads in part.A court employee sent Reuters a copy of the complaint on Wednesday via email.

column1: Jennifer Donnals
column2: press secretary for Governor Haslam
column3: said in an emailed statement: ""We are not able to make comments on pending litigation.""The law protects therapists and counselors from legal action when they cite their personal principles in refusing service
column4: despite a provision in the American Counseling Association's code of ethics barring members from such denials of service.

column1: In the lawsuit
column2: Copas says he is a homosexual man and a resident of Anderson County
column3: Tennessee
column4: while Laieski says he is homosexual and describes himself as a national lesbian
column5: gay
column6: bisexual and transgender rights activist residing in Alexandria
column7: Virginia.With gay marriage becoming a lost cause for opponents - the Supreme Court ruled in June that same-sex couples have the right to marry - a new battleground has become a quest by conservatives in some states to allow people to refuse services to gay men and women on religious grounds. tinyurl.com/hj29fs9

column1: The Tennessee law is among a number of state statutes passed over the last year or so
column2: prohibiting sanctions against businesses
column3: service providers
column4: professionals or clerics who refuse service
column5: in some cases to same-sex couples or in other cases to individuals
column6: based on profoundly held beliefs.Some states
column8: enacted fixes to the measures after large companies and rights groups assailed them as discriminatory. (Reporting by Fiona Ortiz in Chicago; Editing by Steve Orlofsky)"	['Haslam']	['gay']

7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-adviser-idUSKCN0YU2I9	Former Reagan aide helped write Trump foreign policy speech	"
By Mark Hosenball
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON A former senior official in the Reagan administration and prominent Republican foreign policy insider told Reuters he provided input for the late-April foreign policy speech by Donald Trump
column2: the presumptive Republican presidential nominee.""I was asked to contribute material"" for Trump's April 27 speech at the Center for the National Interest
column3: a Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: think tank
column6: said Richard Burt.Burt said he is not part of Trump's campaign.""But I am happy to talk to people looking for advice on foreign policy issues
column8: a managing director of McLarty Associates
column9: a Washington-based consulting firm co-founded by former President Bill Clinton's White House chief of staff and counselor Thomas ""Mack"" McLarty. Burt said he also would be willing to offer foreign policy advice to Hillary Clinton
column11: if she asked for such advice
column13: ""She's not going to.""Burt is also chairman of Global Zero
column14: an independent group devoted to ridding the world of nuclear weapons. Trump told The New York Times in April that he was not sure it would be ""a bad thing"" for the United States if Japan had nuclear weapons
column15: and has said the same about South Korea and Saudi Arabia.

column1: Burt said the main theme he talked about to Trump was the need for the United States to pursue a ""more realist foreign policy
column2: in which the United States would avoid seeking ""regime change"" abroad
column3: and instead make protecting the United States and its interests the main policy goal. Trump
column4: who became the Republican's presumptive nominee last month after the last of his challengers dropped from the party's race
column5: articulated this theme again in a campaign speech late on Tuesday
column6: as he claimed victory in the last Republican nominating contests.Under Reagan
column7: Burt headed the State Department's Bureau of Political-Military Affairs and then its European and Canadian Affairs bureau and served as U.S. ambassador to Germany from 1985 to 1989.

column1: Some of Burt's contemporaries from the administrations of Presidents Reagan
column2: George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush
column3: have publicly denounced Trump's foreign policy views or remained mute.Earlier this year
column4: Trump met with a group of 11 foreign policy advisers
column5: headed by Republican Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama
column6: one of Trump's most outspoken supporters.

column1: Reuters sought comment on the recent activities of Trump's foreign policy team from several of its members and from a campaign spokeswoman. Most declined to comment
column2: and the campaign did not immediately reply to a request for comment. One campaign team member
column3: who asked for anonymity because he is not authorized to comment publicly
column4: said that while the team had held several discussions since Trump's speech
column5: the candidate remains his own most important foreign policy adviser. (Reporting By Mark Hosenball; Editing by John Walcott and Leslie Adler)"	['Trump']	[]
